title: Lessons from scaling Uber and Opendoor | Brian Tolkin (Head of Product at Opendoor, ex-Uber)
key_insights: Operations and product teams work best as 'twin turbine engines' - both needed for optimal performance, not competing functions
Starting in operations provides deep customer understanding that makes for better product leadership
In low-volume businesses, run power analysis before A/B testing to avoid false precision - sometimes trust intuition when data isn't feasible
Jobs-to-be-done framework is most valuable when it forces deeper customer empathy, not as rigid template adherence
Product reviews should focus on making products better, not just accountability - keep under 10 people for best conversations
Staying calm under pressure is learnable through experience and helps teams perform better than reflecting stress
Finding the 'kernel of truth' in ambiguous signals is core to product management - write down all ideas but focus on what really matters
Competition awareness is important but customer focus matters more, especially in large underserved markets

guest_background.current_role: Head of Product and Design at Opendoor

topics_discussed: Transitioning from operations to product management
Building products with heavy operational components
Early Uber stories and UberPOOL global launch
Zillow's failed entry and subsequent partnership
COVID-19 impact on real estate operations
Staying calm under pressure as a leader
Finding technical leverage in ops-heavy businesses
Building teams with different PM skill sets
memorable_quotes: Uber always has this mentality and Opendoor does two of the product operations, twin turbine jet plane where you can fly the plane on one engine for a little bit if you need to, but it's operating most efficiently and effectively if both are working together.
You're never as good as you think you are. You're never as bad as you think you are.
Product is finding the kernel of truth in a sea of ambiguity and signals.
frameworks_mentioned: Twin turbine jet plane model (product + ops)
recommended_for: anyone interested in Uber and Opendoor scaling stories
summary: Brian Tolkin shares lessons from scaling Uber and Opendoor, emphasizing how product and operations teams can work together effectively. He covers practical topics like running product reviews, implementing jobs-to-be-done, and managing experimentation with low sample sizes.
